newsitem.title: INDIA: India Ambuja sees profits staying strong.
newsitem.headline: India Ambuja sees profits staying strong.

text.p: Indian cement maker Gujarat Ambuja announced a strong annual profits performance on Tuesday and scoffed at suggestions that oversupply could slow growth in coming years.

The company said after-tax profits rose 47 percent to 1.48 billion rupees ($41.46 million) in the year which ended on June 30, and raised its dividend to 5.0 rupees per share from 4.0 rupees the previous year.
"With increased production from its cement plants and firm cement prices, the company is expected to do well during the current year," the company said.
But a cement analyst at the Bombay office of a foreign securities firm said he did not think Gujarat Ambuja could maintain its profit growth in 1996/97.

He said a cement surplus in northern India and large capacity additions by Larsen & Toubro and others in western India, Ambuja's major markets, would lead to oversupply that would slow down its profit growth.
But Anil Singhvi, Gujarat Ambuja's treasurer, said he did not agree with those who forecast an oversupply in cement.
"There won't be any surplus in 1996/97," Singhvi told Reuters. "It would be an equally good year if not better."

Some analysts said the firm's profit outlook was somewhat exaggerated because it did not take account of a 15 percent corporate tax known as the minimum alternate tax (MAT) announced by the government in its July 1996 budget.
But Singhvi said MAT was yet to be approved by the parliament, which is debating the budget.
Gujarat Ambuja's fourth cement plant is expected to be commissioned in December 1996, taking its total capacity to 4.5 million tonnes.
The company sold 3.1 million tonnes of cement during the year ended June 30, 1996, compared to 2.0 million tonnes during the previous business year.

The high market capitalisation and liquidity of Gujarat Ambuja was recognised by the recent inclusion of its shares in the revamped benchmark 30-share sensitive (sensex) index of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE).
It is the youngest of the 30 BSE Sensex firms.
The Indian cement industry has been enjoying strong demand, fuelled by robust growth in the economy.

"The growth momentum of 1995/96 continues during the current year also and the first quarter growth of 14 percent which is the highest ever growth achieved by the industry," the Gujarat Ambuja statement said.
"Cement demand will continue to grow at more than 8.0 percent, aided by strong GDP growth," said B. Shashikanth, cement analyst at securities firm Peregrine Capital in Bombay.

He said Gujarat Ambuja was India's lowest-cost cement producer. "This partly stems from its internal efficiencies, as well as quality limestone deposits, which provide cheaper conversion costs," he said in a June cement sector report.
